ANP200.name: Navigating Another Culture
ANP200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP200.description: Understanding how cultural differences shape perspectives and behavior. Adapting to a new cultural setting.

ANP201.name: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
ANP201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP201.description: Origins and diversity of cultural systems. Theories of culture. Patterns of kinship. Religious, economic, and political institutions.

ANP203.name: Introduction to Archaeology
ANP203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP203.description: Theory, methodology, and techniques of archaeology. Applications to questions about past human behavior. History and concepts of archaeology as an anthropological subdiscipline.

ANP204.name: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
ANP204.description: Concepts, methods and theoretical approaches of the field of medical anthropology.

ANP205.name: Navigating United States Culture
ANP205.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP205.description: Anthropological perspectives on social and cultural patterns that shape life in the United States. Includes gender, language, race and ethnicity, subcultures, values, class, manners, food. Ethnographic studies, and methods, as tools to better understand U.S. culture.

ANP206.name: Introduction to Physical Anthropology
ANP206.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP206.description: Problems, data, and methods of physical anthropology. Human genetics, hominid evolution, primate studies, human osteology, and human diversity.

ANP220.name: Gender Relations in Comparative Perspective
ANP220.description: Gender relations in different cultures. Economic and domestic division of labor between the sexes as a factor underlying power differentials.

ANP236.name: The Anthropology of Peace and Justice
ANP236.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP236.description: Anthropological, theoretical, ethnographic, and interdisciplinary approaches to the study of peace and justice. Violence, nonviolence, international law, social movements, economic justice, environmental racism, memory and trauma.

ANP264.name: Great Discoveries in Archaeology
ANP264.description: Great discoveries in archaeology that have captured the public's imagination and shaped Western thought, from Olduvai Gorge and Stonehenge to Macchu Pichu.

ANP270.name: Women and Health: Anthropological and International Perspectives
ANP270.description: Cross cultural perspectives on the health implications of differing life circumstances for women. Women as health-care consumers and providers. Health and women's life cycles.

ANP320.name: Social and Cultural Theory
ANP320.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP320.description: Major theoretical traditions of cultural anthropology. Functionalism, symbolism, structuralism, and contemporary developments.
ANP320.prerequisite: (ANP 201) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP321.name: Anthropology of Social Movements
ANP321.description: How social movements within different cultures around the world organize, create or impede change on the basis of class, religion, race, ethnicity, language, and territory.

ANP325.name: Anthropology of the Environment and Development
ANP325.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP325.description: Anthropological approaches to contemporary environmental and development issues and their inter-relation.

ANP330.name: Race, Ethnicity, and Nation: Anthropological Approaches to Collective Identity
ANP330.description: Understanding race and ethnicity. Models analyzing racial, ethnic, and national identities; boundaries; and collective identities and differentiations. Case studies from cultures worldwide.

ANP362.name: Archaeology of Foragers to Farmers
ANP362.description: Theories, problems, and issues in the study of foraging and farming as adaptive strategies. Archaeological evidence for the appearance and development of food production in prehistory.

ANP363.name: Rise of Civilization
ANP363.description: Archaeological evidence for the appearance and development of the world's earliest prehistoric civilizations. The nature of complex societies and the comparative evolution of states.

ANP364.name: Pseudoarchaeology
ANP364.description: Critical survey and discussion of pseudoarchaeological and pseudoscientific ideas about archaeology, archaeologists, and the human past.

ANP370.name: Culture, Health, and Illness
ANP370.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP370.description: Cross-cultural perspectives on the definition and treatment of illness.
ANP370.prerequisite: (ANP 201 or ANP 204) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP410.name: Anthropology of Latin America
ANP410.description: Comparative analysis of significant social issues confronting contemporary Latin American countries.
ANP410.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ANP411.name: North American Indian Ethnography
ANP411.description: Social and cultural patterns of North American Indian societies. History, economy, politics, social organization, religion, and social change.

ANP412.name: Method and Practice in Digital Heritage
ANP412.description: The application of digital methods and computational approaches to heritage questions, data, materials, collections.
ANP412.prerequisite: ANP 201 or ANP 203 or ANP 204 or ANP 206 or HST 201 or HST 251 or approval of department

ANP415.name: China: Culture and Society
ANP415.description: Socioeconomic and cultural continuity and change from traditional civilization to the contemporary state and the communist period. Village and urban society and their relationships.

ANP417.name: Introduction to Islam in Africa
ANP417.description: Anthropological and historical literature on Islam in Africa. Spread of Islam, colonialism, slave trade, conversion, migration, prayer, Islamic schools, gender, ethnicity, human rights

ANP419.name: Anthropology of the Middle East
ANP419.description: Anthropological literature of the Middle East and North Africa. Cultural variation, religion, ethnicity, kinship, gender, representation, and cultural, political, and economic transformation.

ANP420.name: Language and Culture
ANP420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP420.description: Domain, issues, and methods of cultural linguistics. Relationship between language and culture. Language and ethnicity, status, and role. Pidgin and Creole languages. Crosscultural communication.
ANP420.prerequisite: (ENG 302 or ANP 201 or ANP 320 or LIN 200 or LIN 401) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ANP422.name: Religion and Culture
ANP422.description: The anthropology of religion and the symbolic analysis of ritual. Theoretical and ethnographic literature.
ANP422.prerequisite: (ANP 201) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP425.name: Issues in Medical Anthropology
ANP425.description: Selected topics in the anthropological investigation of health issues with an emphasis on critical analysis of cultural, historical, and conceptual bases for trends in health research. Topics vary.

ANP426.name: Urban Anthropology
ANP426.description: The anthropological approach to urban issues. Cross-cultural perspectives on the informal economy, power, ideology, and community.

ANP429.name: Ethnographic Field Methods
ANP429.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP429.description: Field research in cultural anthropology. Research design, participant observation, relationship of techniques to methods, and ethics.
ANP429.prerequisite: (ANP 201) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ANP429.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANP432.name: American Indian Women
ANP432.description: Role of women in a variety of North American Indian cultures, both traditional and contemporary, using autobiography, life history, historical biography, ethnography, and fiction. Interaction of Indian women and their cultures with Western European and American cultures.

ANP433.name: Contemporary American Indian Communities
ANP433.description: American Indian communities today, both reservation and urban, including issues of tribalization, Pan-Indianism, culture change and revitalization, economic development, federal policy, religious freedom, and gender roles.

ANP436.name: Globalization and Justice: Issues in Political and Legal Anthropology
ANP436.description: Anthropological perspectives on issues of justice linked to global forces of transnational capitalism, economic development, global governance, and international law
ANP436.prerequisite: (ANP 201 or concurrently) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP437.name: Asian Emigrant Communities: A Global Perspective
ANP437.description: Cross-cultural study of emigrant communities of people of Asian descent around the world. Anthropological study of how ideas of race, ethnicity, and national identity are constructed over time and space.

ANP439.name: Human Rights: Anthropological Perspectives
ANP439.description: Cross-cultural study of human rights. Anthropological perspective on the role of law, customs, values, and politics in defining, organizing, and understanding individual and collective rights.
ANP439.prerequisite: (ANP 201 or concurrently) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP440.name: Hominid Fossils
ANP440.description: Theories of human evolution during the past five million years fossil evidence.

ANP441.name: Osteology and Forensic Anthropology
ANP441.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of even years
ANP441.description: Human bone and skeletal biology and analysis. Methods of forensic anthropology. Analysis of skeletal remains, forensic pathology, and forensic archaeology.

ANP443.name: Human Adaptability
ANP443.description: Human adaptation to physical, biological and social environments. Adaptive models from ecology, demography, genetics, physiology, nutrition and medicine. Theoretical and methodological issues in human adaptation studies across various populations.

ANP451.name: European Archaeology
ANP451.description: Patterns of change in technology, subsistence, economy, settlement, social organization, and political complexity from the earliest human occupation through the Iron Age. Major issues in European archaeology.

ANP452.name: North American Archaeology
ANP452.description: Characteristics and processes of North American archaeology on a regional level. Economic, social, political and technological change through time.

ANP455.name: Archaeology of Ancient Egypt
ANP455.semester: Fall of even years, Summer of every year
ANP455.description: The archaeology of ancient Egypt from the Neolithic through the Greco-Roman period.
ANP455.prerequisite: ANP 203 or ANP 264 or approval of department

ANP461.name: Method and Theory in Historical Archaeology
ANP461.semester: Fall of odd years, Summer of every year
ANP461.description: Theory and methodology in historical archaeology and its relation to history and anthropology.

ANP463.name: Laboratory Methods in Archaeology
ANP463.description: Preparation and preservation of archaeological data. Conservation, cleaning, cataloguing, and classification. Analysis of lithics, ceramics, faunal and floral remains, metals, and glass.

ANP464.name: Field Methods in Archaeology
ANP464.description: Field research. Survey, excavation, mapping, data recording, and field laboratory procedures.

ANP465.name: Field Methods in Digital Heritage
ANP465.description: Applied experience in the tools and techniques required to creatively apply digital technology to heritage materials and questions.

ANP471.name: The Anthropology of Alternative Medicine
ANP471.description: Anthropological study of alternative medicine and ethnomedicine in the United States and around the world. Cross-cultural study of concepts of health and illness, diagnosis, and treatment.
ANP471.prerequisite: (ANP 201) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANP476.name: Internship in Anthropology
ANP476.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANP485.name: Foundations of Museum Studies
ANP485.description: Activities, functions, and organization of museums. Changing role of museums as cultural institutions.
ANP485.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANP488.name: Museum Curatorial Practices
ANP488.description: Methods and practices for the development, care, and use of museum collections in research, education, and exhibition activities.
ANP488.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANP489.name: Anthropology Capstone Course (W)
ANP489.description: Integration of the subdivisions of anthropology. Differences between anthropology and other approaches in the social sciences. Future directions of anthropological inquiry.
ANP489.prerequisite: (ANP 201 and ANP 206 and ANP 203) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ANP489.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Anthropology Major.

ANP490.name: Independent Study
ANP490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

ANP491.name: Topics in Anthropology
ANP491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP491.description: Selected topics in sociocultural anthropology, archaeology, physical anthropology, anthropological linguistics, or medical anthropology.

ANP492.name: Special Topics in Museum Studies
ANP492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP492.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings.
ANP492.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANP496.name: Undergraduate Research in Anthropology
ANP496.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP496.description: Independent research in anthropology under the supervision of a faculty member.
ANP496.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Anthropology or approval of department.

ANP810.name: Anthrohistory: Exploring the Crossroads of Anthropology and History
ANP810.description: Recent trends in work between anthropology and history. Emphasis on themes of representation, methodology and epistemology.
ANP810.restrictions: Open to doctoral students or approval of department.

ANP811.name: Knowledge, Memory, and Archives
ANP811.description: Readings in recent anthropological work concerning the construction of historical memory, transmission of knowledge, and the power of representation

ANP812.name: Violence and the State: Anthropological Approaches
ANP812.description: Anthropological perspectives on the state and violence, including

ANP814.name: Capitalism and Modernity
ANP814.description: Capitalism as a global phenomenon with specific attention to colonial and post-colonial contexts. Development of colonial knowledges. Political and economic transformations associated with modernization and developmentalism. Contemporary dynamics of globalization.

ANP815.name: Transnational Processes and Identities
ANP815.description: Critique of anthropological theories of transnationalism and globalization, modernity, diaspora, public culture, and ethnic identity.

ANP820.name: Language and Cultural Meaning
ANP820.description: Intellectual history of 20th century linguistic thinking. Saussure's influence on cultural anthropology. Post-structuralist approaches.

ANP822.name: Religion and Ritual
ANP822.description: The anthropology of religion and the symbolic analysis of ritual. Theoretical and ethnographic literature.

ANP825.name: International Social Science Research: Methods and Praxis
ANP825.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANP825.description: Issues in the design and implementation of anthropological field research. Development of field research proposals.

ANP826.name: International Development: Theory and Practice
ANP826.description: Evolution of international development theory across disciplines. Changing conceptualizations, measurements, processes and effects of development and poverty. Ethnicity, social class, gender, and community influences on socioeconomic processes. Current issues, concerns, and strategic alternatives.

ANP829.name: Research Methods in Cultural Anthropology
ANP829.description: Methodological underpinnings. Project design, field strategies, research techniques, and methods of data analysis.
ANP829.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in Anthropology.

ANP830.name: Cultural and Linguistic Anthropological Theory: Key Issues and Debates
ANP830.description: Key debates in current cultural and linguistic anthropological theory; analytical frameworks and disciplinary genealogies.
ANP830.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology.

ANP831.name: Seminar in Cultural Ecology
ANP831.description: Anthropological theories for understanding culture as system of mediation between humans and environment. Cultural ecological approaches applied to sociocultural change and stability.
ANP831.restrictions: Open only to graduate students. Approval of department.

ANP834.name: Medical Anthropology: Overview
ANP834.description: Anthropological approaches to the study of sickness, disease, and healing. Medical anthropology as a subdiscipline.
ANP834.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology or approval of department.

ANP835.name: Topics in Medical Anthropology
ANP835.description: Seminar in the description and analysis of themes in medical anthropology.
ANP835.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology or approval of department.

ANP836.name: Culture, Resources, and Power
ANP836.description: Production of knowledge/expertise regarding development, environment, culture, and rights; effects of applying these knowledges.

ANP840.name: Biocultural Evolution
ANP840.description: Major contemporary issues in evolutionary theory, taxonomy, and the evolution of biology and culture.
ANP840.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology.

ANP842.name: Human Osteology
ANP842.description: Human bone biology, skeletal anatomy, and osteological analysis.

ANP843.name: Bioarchaeology
ANP843.description: Relationship between skeletal and archaeological data. Reconstruction of mortuary behavior, individual life histories, and social organization. Specific emphasis on research designs.

ANP844.name: Topics in Forensic Anthropology
ANP844.description: Current issues in forensic anthropology. Topics include facial reproduction and identification; laboratory techniques; skeletal histomorphology.

ANP845.name: Paleopathology
ANP845.description: Method and theory related to the study of health and disease in ancient societies through direct and indirect observation of skeletal and dental remains and mummified tissues.

ANP846.name: Quantitative Methods in Anthropology
ANP846.description: Statistical and data analysis methods, as they apply to anthropological questions.
ANP846.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology.

ANP850.name: Principles of Archaeological Analysis
ANP850.description: Formal, spatial, and temporal dimensions of archaeological research design. Appropriate analytic techniques.

ANP851.name: The Analysis of Mortuary Practices
ANP851.description: Analysis of mortuary practices, from an archaeological perspective. Examining death from sociocultural, archaeological and bioarchaeological views. History of analysis of mortuary practice.

ANP854.name: Archaeological Theory
ANP854.description: Archaeological theory and the nature of the archaeological record. Use of archaeological data to test social theories of past human behavior.

ANP858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
ANP858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

ANP859.name: Gender, Justice, and Environmental Change: Methods and Application
ANP859.description: Methods and case studies related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Methodological and fieldwork issues from a feminist perspective in international and intercultural contexts. Qualitative and quantitative methods for integrating social and environmental data.

ANP870.name: Professional Issues in Anthropology
ANP870.description: Ethics and professionalism in field work, behavior in academic and non-academic situations.
ANP870.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Anthropology or approval of department.

ANP886.name: Fundamentals of Museum Studies
ANP886.description: Introduction to the history of museums and current practices, standards, issues and ethics related to education, administration, visitor studies and the development, care and use of museum collections.
ANP886.restrictions: Open to lifelong graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or in the Department of Anthropology or in the Department of History. Approval of department.

ANP887.name: Museums and Technology
ANP887.description: Theoretical and practical approaches to the way museums, zoos, gardens and other cultural sites use digital media, the web, interactive media and databases to engage the public, create virtual exhibits and web presences, and manage collections. Ways technologies are changing the definition of visitors and visitor experiences and the definitions of museums.
ANP887.restrictions: Open to graduate students or lifelong graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters.

ANP890A.name: Individual Readings
ANP890A.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP890A.description: Advanced study, based on prior preparation, under faculty direction.
ANP890A.restrictions: Open only to graduate students. Approval of department.

ANP890B.name: Individual Research
ANP890B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP890B.description: Graduate student projects under faculty direction.

ANP892.name: Seminar in Anthropology
ANP892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP892.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in Anthropology. Approval of department.

ANP893.name: Internship in the Professional Applications of Anthropology
ANP893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP893.description: Supervised professional experience in federal or state agencies, nonprofit organizations, or corporations related to the professional practice of anthropology.

ANP894.name: Forensic Anthropology Internship in Forensic Pathology
ANP894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP894.description: Supervised professional internship in postmortem analysis. Students will attend autopsies and learn procedures that are relevant for forensic anthropology. Individual research project.

ANP895.name: Special Topics in Museum Studies
ANP895.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

ANP897.name: Practicum in Museum Studies
ANP897.semester: On Demand, On Demand, On Demand

ANP899.name: Master's Thesis Research
ANP899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in Anthropology. Approval of department.

ANP999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
ANP999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANP999.restrictions: Open to graduate students. Approval of department.
